condition.description:
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a form of arthritis that causes pain, swelling, stiffness and loss of function in your joints. It can affect any joint but is common in the wrist and fingers.

More women than men get rheumatoid arthritis. It often starts in middle age and is most common in older people. But children and young adults can also get it. You might have the disease for only a short time, or symptoms might come and go. The severe form can last a lifetime.

Rheumatoid arthritis is different from osteoarthritis, the common arthritis that often comes with older age. RA can affect body parts besides joints, such as your eyes, mouth and lungs. RA is an autoimmune disease, which means the arthritis results from your immune system attacking your body's own tissues.

No one knows what causes rheumatoid arthritis. Genes, environment and hormones might contribute. Treatments include medicine, lifestyle changes and surgery. These can slow or stop joint damage and reduce pain and swelling.

NIH: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

symptoms: Can affect any joint, but most common in wrists and fingers

carousel_items: Take with food to avoid getting diarrhea.
Don't drink alcohol while on Arthrotec.
Don't take other anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs) without talking to your doctor or pharmacist.
Can cause swelling in the legs, abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, and an upset stomach.
Don't take antacids with magnesium since they can interact with Arthrotec.
Take Arthrotec at the smallest dose possible for the shortest amount of time to lower your risk of a heart attack.
Don't give Arthrotec to anyone that it's not prescribed to, especially women who are pregnant or are trying to become pregnant.

basics.benefits_moa: Arthrotec contains two medications. Diclofenac stops the body from making chemicals that cause inflammation and pain. Misoprostol protects the stomach from irritation.
basics.bottom_line: Arthrotec is an okay medication used to treat pain and swelling caused by arthritis. However, because of the risk of heart attack, it's recommended to limit the amount you take.
downsides: Can't be used in pregnant or breastfeeding women.
You should avoid alcohol while on Arthrotec since it can increase your risk of stomach issues.
If you're taking it on a regular basis, you'll need to get labs done to make sure your liver and kidneys aren't being affected.

downsides_processed.orig: Can't be used in pregnant or breastfeeding women.
You should avoid alcohol while on Arthrotec since it can increase your risk of stomach issues.
If you're taking it on a regular basis, you'll need to get labs done to make sure your liver and kidneys aren't being affected.

upsides: Clinical studies show that Arthrotec is better at relieving arthritis pain than acetaminophen (Tylenol).
Can be used as needed to treat pain and swelling.
Available as a generic.

risks_warnings.title: Heart attack or stroke
risks_warnings.description: Arthrotec can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. Take the lowest dose for the shortest time possible to lower your risk. Never take Arthrotec during the first two weeks after having heart surgery.

description_processed.orig: Arthrotec can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. Take the lowest dose for the shortest time possible to lower your risk. Never take Arthrotec during the first two weeks after having heart surgery.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Arthrotec can cause serious stomach problems that include inflammation, ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. The chances that a stomach problem will occur is worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers

description_processed.orig: Arthrotec can cause serious stomach problems that include inflammation, ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. The chances that a stomach problem will occur is worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time.

risks_warnings.title: Bruising or bleeding
risks_warnings.description: You can bruise more easily while using Arthrotec. If you're bleeding, it can take longer than normal for the bleeding to stop. Tell your doctor about all of your medical conditions and medications before starting Arthrotec. Don't take Arthrotec while using other blood thinning medications unless your doctor tells you it is safe.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Arthrotec can cause serious allergic reactions. These reactions can make it difficult to breath or cause a severe rash that can be life-threatening. Stop taking Arthrotec and report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor or get medical help right away.

risks_warnings.title: Lowers kidney function
risks_warnings.description: Arthrotec, and similar medications in the NSAID family, can lower kidney function or cause permanent kidney damage. Taking the lowest dose for the shortest amount of time necessary can lower your risk of kidney problems. It's important to get lab tests to check your kidney function periodically if you use Arthrotec for long periods of time.
risk_factors: Taking ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)

risks_warnings.title: Increased blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Arthrotec can raise your blood pressure. If you have high blood pressure and need a medication for the long-term treatment of pain, talk with your doctor since a different medication may be better for you.

Higher aspirin doses can be used to treat occasional pain, swelling, and fever. Using ibuprofen or acetaminophen (Tylenol) instead can lower your risk of serious bleeding.

clock.tip: Take with food or milk to lower stomach upset.

basics.benefits_moa: Aspirin is a salicylate and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain. It also prevents blood platelets from forming clots, which thins your blood.
basics.bottom_line: A low dose of Aspirin (81mg) every day can protect your heart, but it's not the best medicine to take for pain, swelling, or fever.
downsides: Not a preferred medication for treating pain, swelling, or fever due to its high risk of bleeding.
NSAIDs (like ibuprofen and naproxen) and acetaminophen (Tylenol) are better for treating pain and fever thank aspirin.
Aspirin raises your risk of bleeding, especially when used with other blood thinner medications like warfarin (Coumadin).
Studies show that using higher doses of Aspirin (162 mg or more) every day raises your risk of stomach bleeding and doesn't provide any additional heart protection.

carousel_items: Starts working in 1 to 3 hours.
Take it with a meal or a snack to prevent an upset stomach.
Can make you bruise or bleed more easily and it can also cause stomach ulcers.
Don't take it with other blood thinners, like aspirin, unless your doctor tells you it's safe.
Can hurt your kidneys, so don't use it if you have a history of kidney problems.

basics.benefits_moa: Celebrex is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain.
basics.bottom_line: Celebrex works well for treating pain and causes less upset stomach than other NSAIDs.
downsides: It's not available as a generic medication, so it's more expensive than many alternatives.
The longer you take Celebrex, the more likely you are to have stomach problems, including inflammation, ulcers, and bleeding. This can also happen if you take Celebrex on an empty stomach.
Like all NSAIDs, it can raise your risk of blood clots, heart attack, or a stroke.
Can also affect your kidneys or cause permanent kidney damage if taken for a long time.

Lasts longer than Ibuprofen.

basics.benefits_moa: Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain.
basics.bottom_line: Indomethacin works well for mild to moderate pain and swelling, but it shouldn't be used long-term since it has some serious side effects.
downsides: Indomethacin can cause serious heart and stomach problems. The risk goes up the longer you take it, but problems can happen at any time. Don't take Indomethacin any longer than your doctor recommends.
Indomethacin raises your risk of bleeding, especially when taken with other blood-thinning medicines.
There are similar medicines that you don't have to take as often and can work just as well.
Not a good choice if you have kidney, liver, or stomach problems.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Indomethacin can cause serious allergic reactions.  These reactions can make it difficult to breath or cause a severe rash that can be life threatening. If you have Asthma, don't take Indomethacin if you're experiencing a runny nose (Rhinitis) with or without nasal polyps.  Also, don't take Indomethacin if you've experienced an asthma attack after taking aspirin or other NSAID type medications.  Stop taking Indomethacin and report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor right away.

risks_warnings.title: Bruising or Bleeding

carousel_items: Donâ€™t give up on Plaquenil, it can take 2-4 months to take effect.
Take Plaquenil with milk to help decrease nausea.
If you have difficulty swallowing Plaquenil, you can crush it, and mix it in jam or jelly.

While taking Plaquenil it is important to wear sunglasses in bright light to protect your eyes from damage. When you canâ€™t avoid sunlight, be sure to use sunscreen, put on a long-sleeved shirt, pants, and a hat.
Stay away from alcohol while taking Plaquenil.
Certain medications can interact with Plaquenil, so to be safe, tell your doctor about other medications and supplements you may be taking.

basics.benefits_moa: Plaquenil is called a DMARD, a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug. It prevents your body from activating cells that cause inflammation.
basics.bottom_line: Plaquenil is a great medication for rheumatoid arthritis and comes with less side effects than other DMARDs.
downsides: You will likely have to take additional medications like Methotrexate to keep your RA in control.
In some people, small particles develop in the eyes, so youâ€™ll have to get your eyes checked once per year.
It can take up to 6 months before the full benefits of Plaquenil are felt.
Many people have nausea, stomach cramps, and diarrhea when they first start taking Plaquenil.

upsides: Plaquenil has been shown to improve physical function in up to 80% of patients.
Plaquenil and similar DMARD medications help minimize joint damage, decrease symptoms and lessen future complications.
Plaquenil is an excellent choice for people who have difficulty tolerating newer biologic medications.
A generic form of Plaquenil is available.

risks_warnings.description: Doctors should be completely familiar with the medication label before prescribing Plaquenil.

risks_warnings.title: Drug resistance
risks_warnings.description: Plaquenil is not effective against chloroquine-resistant strains of P. falciparum malaria.

risks_warnings.title: Children
risks_warnings.description: Children are especially sensitive to medications like Plaquenil, which contain 4-aminoquinoline. Ingestion of small amounts has caused death in children. So to be safe, keep Plaquenil out of the reach of children.

description_processed.orig: Children are especially sensitive to medications like Plaquenil, which contain 4-aminoquinoline. Ingestion of small amounts has caused death in children. So to be safe, keep Plaquenil out of the reach of children.

risks_warnings.title: Pregnancy
risks_warnings.description: Plaquenil should only be used in pregnancy for malaria when using it outweighs its harmful effects. The IV form of Plaquenil has been shown to cross the placenta rapidly and can harm the baby.

description_processed.orig: Plaquenil should only be used in pregnancy for malaria when using it outweighs its harmful effects. The IV form of Plaquenil has been shown to cross the placenta rapidly and can harm the baby.

risks_warnings.title: Damage to retina of eye
risks_warnings.description: Plaquenil can cause blurred vision, difficulty reading, and damage to the retina of the eye during or after long-term treatment. The chance of this happening is less with lower doses. Before starting treatment, your doctor may send you to an ophthalmologist (eye doctor) to carefully examine both eyes. This should be repeated at least once a year. If you have trouble seeing color or clearly, call your doctor and stop taking Plaquenil. These effects may last even after stopping the medicine.
risk_factors: Taking Plaquenil in higher than recommended doses

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Plaquenil lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful. Avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert

carousel_items: The dose and duration on how long you need the medicine depends on your condition and response.
Take it exactly as your doctor prescribed.
Take with food to decrease stomach upset.
Can cause trouble sleeping. Take in the morning or 2-3 hours before bed if more than one dose is needed.
Can cause changes in mood, blood pressure, blood sugar, and water retention.
You should check your blood pressure and blood sugar when taking this medicine if you already have high blood pressure or diabetes.
A taper is is often needed to stop the medicine, especially if you've been on it for more than 1 week.

clock.tip: Works better if taken with a high-fat meal.

basics.benefits_moa: Prednisone is a corticosteroid that's similar to what your body naturally makes. It reduces swelling and other immune responses that can cause you pain, discomfort, or harm.
basics.bottom_line: Prednisone is a common oral corticosteroid that's great for controlling the unwanted symptoms from your immune responses and will make you feel better. There are lots of side effects but most of are tolerable or can be managed.
downsides: Lots of side effects, especially with long term use.
Short-term use can cause mood changes, trouble sleeping and increase in blood pressure, blood sugar, and possible water retention.
Long-term use can cause problems with skin, bone, eye health and put you at a higher risk for infections.
People with certain conditions will have to pay extra attention to their symptoms or may have to adjust the dose of other medicines when taking Prednisone.
When using corticosteroids for more than 1 week, you will need to work with a doctor to get off the medicine slowly.
Only available as an oral medicine so the rest of your body will be exposed to the medicine.

Useful for many conditions.

Long-term use in suppressing the immune system from causing your body harm, like many autoimmune related conditions.

risks_warnings.title: Adrenal suppression (HPA axis suppression)
risks_warnings.description: Adrenal suppression leading to adrenal crisis can occur if you lower your dose or stop taking Prednisone too quickly. Symptoms include joint or muscle pain, extreme low energy and depression. Changes in your Prednisone dose need to be done slowly over time. Talk to your doctor before you make any changes or stop the medication.
risk_factors: Lowering dose or stopping too quickly especially after long-term treatment
Stress such as trauma, surgery or infection

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk for infections
risks_warnings.description: If you take Prednisone for a long time it can increase your risk of all types of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight and be more serious. Be careful not to be in contact with anyone who has the chicken pox or measles. If you had tuberculosis (TB) in the past your doctor will need to monitor you while taking Prednisone. You may need to take medicine to prevent getting it or treat it if your TB comes back. Talk to your doctor before taking Prednisone if you haven't had vaccinations against certain viral diseases, are under stress or regularly around sick people.
risk_factors: Contact with people who have viral illness
History of bacterial or viral conditions

risks_warnings.title: Kaposi's sarcoma
risks_warnings.description: Itâ€™s rare, but taking Prednisone for a long period of time, can increase your risk of Kaposiâ€™s sarcoma, a type of cancer that can affect both the skin and internal organs. Your doctor will monitor you closely while you're taking Prednisone and if this develops, will work with you to slowly lower your dose and stop the medication.

risks_warnings.title: Eye problems
risks_warnings.description: Prednisone may cause cataracts or glaucoma, increased eye pressure and possibly eye nerve damage. You may also be more at risk for certain eye infections. Don't take if you have herpes simplex of the eye.  Let your doctor know if you have blurry vision, eye pain or any vision changes.

risks_warnings.title: Psychiatric changes
risks_warnings.description: Like most corticosteroid medicines, Prednisone may cause changes in your mood or behavior. Tell your doctor right away if you become depressed, have mood swings, trouble sleeping, irritability or anxiety, hyperactivity,  delusions or hallucinations while taking this medicine. If you need to make any changes or slowly taper your dose, talk to your doctor first.

risks_warnings.title: Bone effects
risks_warnings.description: Prednisone can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your childâ€™s height during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Prednisone can thin the bones and decrease the growth rate in children. Talk to the doctor about medicine choices that won't negatively affect growth. Use the lowest possible dose to treat the condition and have the doctor monitor your childâ€™s height during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Taking Prednisone if your pregnant or breast-feeding can harm your unborn baby. If you need to take a systemic corticosteroid during pregnancy, the lowest dose that will help treat your condition should be used for the shortest time, especially during your first trimester. Your doctor will let you know if there are other medicine choices that are safer (e.g. inhaled steroids for asthma). If you're taking Prednisone to treat an autoimmune condition like rheumatoid arthritis or for antirejection treatment after a transplant, there are disease registries that you'll need to contact so make sure you talk to your doctor.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach and intestinal problems
risks_warnings.description: Taking Prednisone increases the risk of injury to the lining of your stomach and intestine including irritation, tears/holes and ulcers. You should avoid alcohol/alcoholic beverages because it can worsen stomach irritation. Tell your doctor or get medical care right away if you have stomach pain, notice blood or dark colored stools when you go to the bathroom.
risk_factors: Active or history of stomach or duodenal ulcers
Taking Prednisone with other medicine that can cause stomach problems

basics.benefits_moa: Sulfasalazine is an anti-inflammatory drug that reduces inflammation and pain. It treats inflammatory bowel diseases and rheumatoid arthritis.
basics.bottom_line: Sulfasalazine is used for moderate to severe inflammatory bowel conditions, and with other meds for treating rheumatoid arthritis.
downsides: You need to have blood tests every 3 months when taking Sulfasalazine.
Sulfasalazine isn't a good option if you have kidney or liver disease.
Can't take Sulfasalazine if you are allergic to aspirin or sulfa medications.
Sulfasalazine shouldn't be used if you are breastfeeding.

risks_warnings.title: Kidney damage
risks_warnings.description: Complete blood counts should be done before starting Sulfasalazine and every other week during the first three months of treatment. Since kidney damage can occur, you'll need a urinalysis and an assessment of your kidney function periodically during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Complete blood counts should be done before starting Sulfasalazine and every other week during the first three months of treatment. Since kidney damage can occur, you'll need a urinalysis and an assessment of your kidney function periodically during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Serious skin reactions
risks_warnings.description: Severe and possibly fatal reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis) can happen anytime and as early as the first day while taking Sulfasalazine. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if you notice sores or fluid-filled blisters on your skin, lips, or inside your mouth. You won't be able to re-start Sulfasalazine after this reaction.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Severe hypersensitivity reactions can include internal organ involvement, such as hepatitis (liver), nephritis (kidney), myocarditis (heart), blood abnormalities, or pneumonitis (lungs).

carousel_items: If taking Diclofenac sodium by mouth, take it with a meal or a snack to prevent an upset stomach.
Can cause stomach ulcers, especially if taking it by mouth often.
Can make you bruise or bleed more easily. You shouldn't take any other 'blood thinner' medications unless your doctor tells you it's safe.
Don't use it the first two weeks after a heart surgery.
Can affect your kidneys' ability to work as well.

If using the skin (topical) gel, use the dosing card it comes with to make sure you measure the correct dose. You also won't have many of the same side effects that you would if taking Diclofenac sodium by mouth.

basics.benefits_moa: Diclofenac sodium is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). It blocks the inflammation process in your body, which relieves swelling and pain.
basics.bottom_line: Diclofenac sodium works well for pain and causes less upset stomach than other NSAIDs.
downsides: Can cause serious stomach problems like inflammation, ulcers, and bleeding. The chances that a stomach problem will occur is worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time while taking it.
Like all NSAIDs, it can raise your risk of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke.
Can lower kidney function or cause permanent kidney damage. These problems are more likely the longer you take it.

risks_warnings.title: Heart attack or stroke
risks_warnings.description: Diclofenac sodium can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. Take the lowest dose for the shortest time possible to lower your risk. Never take Diclofenac sodium during the first two weeks after having heart surgery.

description_processed.orig: Diclofenac sodium can increase your chance of having blood clots, heart attack, or stroke. Take the lowest dose for the shortest time possible to lower your risk. Never take Diclofenac sodium during the first two weeks after having heart surgery.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Diclofenac sodium can cause serious stomach problems that include inflammation, ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. The chances that a stomach problem will occur is worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time.
risk_factors: History of stomach bleeding or ulcers

description_processed.orig: Diclofenac sodium can cause serious stomach problems that include inflammation, ulcers, bleeding, and holes in the stomach or intestines. The chances that a stomach problem will occur is worse the longer you take this medication, but it can happen at any time.

risks_warnings.title: Bruising or bleeding
risks_warnings.description: You can bruise more easily while using Diclofenac sodium. If you're bleeding, it can take longer than normal for the bleeding to stop. Tell your doctor about all of your medical conditions and medications before starting Diclofenac sodium. Don't take Diclofenac sodium while using other blood thinning medications unless your doctor tells you it is safe.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Diclofenac sodium can cause serious allergic reactions. These reactions can make it difficult to breath or cause a severe rash that can be life-threatening. Stop taking Diclofenac sodium and report any skin rash, fever, swelling, or trouble breathing to a doctor or get medical help right away.

risks_warnings.title: Lowers kidney function
risks_warnings.description: Diclofenac sodium, and similar medications in the NSAID family, can lower kidney function or cause permanent kidney damage. Taking the lowest dose for the shortest amount of time necessary can lower your risk of kidney problems. It's important to get lab tests to check your kidney function periodically if you use Diclofenac sodium for long periods of time.
risk_factors: Taking ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)

risks_warnings.title: Increased blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Diclofenac sodium can raise your blood pressure.  Most people usually don't feel any differently when their blood pressure is high, so check your blood pressure periodically to watch out for it. If you have high blood pressure and need a medication for the long-term treatment of pain, talk with your doctor since a different medication may be better for you.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to unborn babies
risks_warnings.description: If you're in the late stages of pregnancy (more than 30 weeks), taking Diclofenac sodium can increase the risk of a heart defect in your baby. Talk with your doctor before using this medication while pregnant.

basics.benefits_moa: Minocycline is a tetracycline antibiotic. It stops bacteria by preventing them from reproducing and repairing themselves.
basics.bottom_line: Minocycline is an effective way to treat certain skin infections, acne, and rosacea, but you'll need to use barrier methods of birth control since it can make birth control pills less effective and cause birth defects.
downsides: It can make birth control pills less effective, so people should use barrier methods of birth control like condoms or diaphragms while on Minocycline.

risks_warnings.title: Diarrhea from a superinfection (an infection that happens after, or in addition to, an earlier infection)
risks_warnings.description: Taking antibiotics, like Minocycline can increase your chance of getting certain fungal or bacterial infections that causes diarrhea and can be contagious. carousel_items: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

basics.benefits_moa: Remicade is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Remicade is very effective at calming down your immune system, but you have to get each dose at your doctor's office and watch out for serious side effects.
downsides: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Remicade has almost two decades of clinical trial data and real-life experience with millions of people who have used it.
Initial dosing to introduce Remicade to your body might be a hassle, but then you only need to take it every 6-8 weeks depending on your condition.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Remicade has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Remicade is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Remicade. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Malignancy
risks_warnings.description: Based on how Remicade works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Remicade.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Remicade can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while you're taking Remicade since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

risks_warnings.title: Blood problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Liver injury

carousel_items: Rituximab is given as an IV infusion by trained medical staff in a clinic or hospital.
You'll need to be monitored in the clinic in case you have a serious or life-threatening reaction during the infusion, but you can take other medications that'll lower your risk of this happening.
It's very important that you read the Medication Guide before you start taking Rituximab.
Rituximab lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, a cough that doesn't go away, or flu-like symptoms.
Use effective birth control while you're taking Rituximab and for 12 months after you finish treatment.
Don't get live vaccines while you're taking Rituximab.

basics.benefits_moa: Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody. It targets a specific protein on white blood cells that makes it easier for your immune system to find and destroy cancerous cells. It also relieves symptoms and slows the progression of Rheumatoid Arthritis.
basics.bottom_line: Rituximab is effective for treating multiple types of cancer and arthritis. That said, you'll need to watch for possibly serious side effects, especially infusion reactions.
downsides: Only your doctor or other trained medical staff can administer Rituximab, so you'll need to go into an office or clinic for every dose.
Not the best choice if you have heart problems.
Rituximab can stay in your body for up to 6 months after you complete treatment. Men and women who are able to have children need to use birth control for up to one year after finishing Rituximab.
Discuss with your doctor the serious heart, kidney, liver, or stomach problems that can happen while on Rituximab.

downsides_processed.orig: Only your doctor or other trained medical staff can administer Rituximab, so you'll need to go into an office or clinic for every dose.
Not the best choice if you have heart problems.
Rituximab can stay in your body for up to 6 months after you complete treatment. Men and women who are able to have children need to use birth control for up to one year after finishing Rituximab.
Discuss with your doctor the serious heart, kidney, liver, or stomach problems that can happen while on Rituximab.

upsides: Treats leukemia, lymphoma, and blood vessel inflammation.
Also treats moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis that hasn't responded to anti-TNF treatment (but you'll need to take methotrexate too).

The chance of having a reaction to the infusion is highest during your first dose, but the risk decreases each time you get Rituximab. It usually happens within 30 minutes to 2 hours after starting the infusion.
Rituximab is a targeted therapy that works differently than chemotherapy. Both work well when they're taken together, especially when treating CLL and NHL.

risks_warnings.title: Skin and mouth reactions
risks_warnings.description: Severe and possibly fatal reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, pemphigus)  can happen anytime and as early as the first day while taking Rituximab. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if you notice sores or fluid-filled blisters on your skin, lips or inside your mouth or peeling skin that's painful. You may not be able to re-start Rituximab after this reaction.

risks_warnings.title: Kidney injury
risks_warnings.description: Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) happens when cancer cells are broken down very quickly and damage the kidneys. The damage can be so bad that people need dialysis. If you're taking Rituximab for a cancer condition your doctor can give you medicines and take measures to prevent this reaction.

carousel_items: Cimzia is a medicine that's injected just under the skin (subcutaneous). It can be given in your doctor's office or you can do it yourself at home.
It can take multiple doses before you start to see any effects, so don't change your dose without talking to your doctor.
Tell your doctor if you have night sweats, persistent fever, fatigue, weight loss, or swollen lymph nodes.
You'll need to have a TB (tuberculosis) test before you start Cimzia and periodically during treatment.
Don't get any live vaccines while you're taking Cimzia since they may not work as well. Wait at least 3 months after you've stopped taking Cimzia before getting a live vaccine.

basics.benefits_moa: Cimzia is a monoclonal antibody. It lowers inflammation in the body by blocking a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor).
basics.bottom_line: Cimzia is an effective medicine to calm down your immune system, but it can be expensive and it requires a lot of monitoring while you're taking it.
downsides: Can lower your immune system's ability to fight infections. You can get serious infections such as TB (tuberculosis) and infections caused by viruses, fungi, or bacteria.
Can have a higher risk for causing bladder infections, rash, and upper respiratory infections (cold or flu) compared to other similar medicines.
Cimzia can increase the risk of lymphoma, leukemia, and other cancers.
Requires routine tests to check for infections.
Not a good choice if you have a history of heart failure, nervous system problems, or hepatitis B.
There's no generic available and it can be very expensive.

downsides_processed.orig: Can lower your immune system's ability to fight infections. You can get serious infections such as TB (tuberculosis) and infections caused by viruses, fungi, or bacteria.
Can have a higher risk for causing bladder infections, rash, and upper respiratory infections (cold or flu) compared to other similar medicines.
Cimzia can increase the risk of lymphoma, leukemia, and other cancers.
Requires routine tests to check for infections.
Not a good choice if you have a history of heart failure, nervous system problems, or hepatitis B.
There's no generic available and it can be very expensive.

upsides: In studies, people with RA (rheumatoid arthritis) taking methotrexate had improved symptoms when Cimzia was added to methotrexate.
Cimzia is as effective as other similar medicines for Crohn's disease. It can be an option for people taking other RA medications that have too many side effects of don't work anymore.
Cimzia lasts longer in the body than other RA medications, letting it work longer.
Available in a prefilled syringe. This can make it easier to give yourself the injection.

drugs.name: Cimzia

carousel_items_processed.orig: Cimzia is a medicine that's injected just under the skin (subcutaneous). It can be given in your doctor's office or you can do it yourself at home.
It can take multiple doses before you start to see any effects, so don't change your dose without talking to your doctor.
Tell your doctor if you have night sweats, persistent fever, fatigue, weight loss, or swollen lymph nodes.
You'll need to have a TB (tuberculosis) test before you start Cimzia and periodically during treatment.
Don't get any live vaccines while you're taking Cimzia since they may not work as well. Wait at least 3 months after you've stopped taking Cimzia before getting a live vaccine.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Cimzia can increase the risk for developing serious infections, such as TB (tuberculosis) or infections caused by viruses, fungi, or bacteria. These can be life-threatening, so call your doctor right away if you develop a serious infection or a blood infection.
risk_factors: Medications that lower immune system function

description_processed.orig: Cimzia can increase the risk for developing serious infections, such as TB (tuberculosis) or infections caused by viruses, fungi, or bacteria. These can be life-threatening, so call your doctor right away if you develop a serious infection or a blood infection.

risks_warnings.description: Cimzia can increase the risk of lymphoma, leukemia, and other cancers. Talk to your doctor if you have night sweats, persistent fever, fatigue, weight loss, or swollen lymph nodes.

risks_warnings.title: Tuberculosis | Hepatitis B
risks_warnings.description: You'll need to have a TB (tuberculosis) test before you start Cimzia and periodically during treatment. You should treat latent TB before starting Cimzia. If you're a carrier of HBV (hepatitis B virus), taking Cimzia can cause reactivation of the virus. You'll need routine tests during and after treatment with Cimzia.

carousel_items: Enbrel is available as a single-use prefilled syringe, single-use prefilled SureClick Autoinjector, and multiple-use vial. You and your doctor can discuss which is best for you.
The autoinjector can be stored at room temperature for up to 14 days and can't be refrigerated again.
Enbrel is a medication that's injected under the skin (subcutaneous). Your doctor can give you your first dose, then let you self-inject it once so you learn how to do it correctly.
Enbrel lowers the your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you come down with a fever, cough, or notice flu-like symptoms.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start using Enbrel.
Tell your doctor if you have an allergy to latex since the syringe needle cover has latex in it.
Don't inject Enbrel into skin that's red, bruised, or irritated. Rotate your injection areas to avoid skin reactions.
As with all injection medicines, store away from children and throw used syringes away in a protective container, and not in the trash.

basics.benefits_moa: Enbrel is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Enbrel is very effective at calming down your immune system, but it's expensive, you have to take into account the hassle of injections and traveling with the medication.
downsides: It's an injection.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Enbrel lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.

You're first dose of Enbrel will need to be given at your doctor's office. If you decide not to self-inject and don't have someone to do it for you, you'll need to continue to see your doctor for each dose.
You'll need to properly dispose of the needle, syringes, or Pen in a special (FDA-approved) sharps container.
Because it needs to be refrigerated until you use it, if you're traveling, you'll need to carry it in a cooler with an ice pack.

downsides_processed.orig: It's an injection.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Enbrel is the first biologic approved for moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis.
It has an established safety profile for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
Available as a single-use syringe and SureClick auto-injector pen which may be more convenient and easier for some people to use.
People taking Enbrel for rheumatoid arthritis showed significant improvement and were able to reduce the dose or stop immunosuppressant medicines.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Enbrel has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Enbrel has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Enbrel may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Enbrel is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Enbrel can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Enbrel. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Malignancy
risks_warnings.description: Based on how Enbrel works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Enbrel.

description_processed.orig: Based on how Enbrel works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Enbrel.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Enbrel can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while your taking Enbrel since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

carousel_items: Keep the Orencia self-injection refrigerated, but let it rest at room temperature for 30 to 60 minutes before using it.
Each time you use Orencia, be sure to rotate the sites you chose to inject it in. Don't inject it where your skin is tender, bruised, red, or scaly.
If you decide to go with the IV version of Orencia, you will only need to get infusions once a month. The self-injections however need to be taken once a week.
If you get the IV infusion, stay hydrated, try to relax, and ask your nurse to apply dry heat (instant warm packs) to your arm to help find your good veins.

basics.benefits_moa: Orencia is called a DMARD, a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug. It prevents your body from activating cells that cause inflammation.
basics.bottom_line: Orencia slows the progress of rheumatoid arthritis, but can also have serious side effects.
downsides: You'll have to get your blood tested regularly while taking Orencia.
You'll probably have to take other medications to help treat your RA symptoms.
Orencia is pretty expensive.
The IV infusion form of Orencia can cause a reaction, which ranges from a slight itching or warm feeling to more serious complications like low blood pressure and chest pain.
Because RA is chronic disease, you'll likely take Orencia for many years.

downsides_processed.orig: You'll have to get your blood tested regularly while taking Orencia.

Orencia is pretty expensive.
The IV infusion form of Orencia can cause a reaction, which ranges from a slight itching or warm feeling to more serious complications like low blood pressure and chest pain.
Because RA is chronic disease, you'll likely take Orencia for many years.

upsides: Helps minimize joint damage, lowers symptoms, and prevents future problems.
In a 2-year study that used IV Orencia with methotrexate, more than half of the people had remission and the majority felt significantly better.
People taking [name-common] had no new joint damage after two years.
Taking Orencia allows RA patients to use less prednisone, a steroid that has many side effects.
Orencia can be used without other medications for RA.

risks_warnings.description: You shouldn't take Orencia with TNF antagonists (other DMARDs like Remicade, Humira, and Enbrel). People taking any of these combinations can experience more infections.

risks_warnings.title: Live vaccines

carousel_items: Remicade is a medication that's given as an infusion at your doctor's office or clinic.
It's very important to read the patient Medication Guide when you first start using Remicade.
It's possible to get an allergic reaction to Remicade either immediately during the treatment or a several days after stopping it. Your doctor can give you medicines that'll lower this risk.
You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

If you have a young child, let their doctor know if you were on Remicade while pregnant or nursing. It can increase their risk of infections for several months after your last dose and can delay their vaccine schedule.

basics.benefits_moa: Remicade is a biologic response modifier. It works in the immune system to block a protein called TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Blocking TNF relieves symptoms and prevents disease progression.
basics.bottom_line: Remicade is very effective at calming down your immune system, but you have to get each dose at your doctor's office and watch out for serious side effects.
downsides: You have to get every dose through an IV infusion at your doctor's office.
It's expensive because there's no generic available yet.

Remicade has a higher risk of serious infusion-related side effects during or after it's given since it's injected right into your veins. Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose that may lower this risk.

Remicade lowers your ability to fight infection and can cause serious life-threatening illness. The risk is greater if you take other drugs that lower your immune system, have an active infection, diabetes, or had tuberculosis (TB) in the past.
Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

Not the best choice if you have heart failure.

Talk to your baby's doctor if you're pregnant or breast-feeding. When women in a study took Remicade, the medicine was found in their breast milk 2 to 3 days after each dose, and in the baby's blood 6 months after they were born.

upsides: Treats certain types of arthritis and gastrointestinal conditions caused by an overactive immune system.
Remicade has almost two decades of clinical trial data and real-life experience with millions of people who have used it.
Initial dosing to introduce Remicade to your body might be a hassle, but then you only need to take it every 6-8 weeks depending on your condition.

You'll need to have a TB test before you start taking Remicade and periodically during treatment.

Remicade lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, cough, or flu-like symptoms. Children seem to get more infections than adults, so keep a close eye on them.

risks_warnings.title: Serious allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Remicade has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

description_processed.orig: Remicade has been reported to cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (life-threatening condition with swelling with or without hives). If you notice these symptoms after your dose or days later, call your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. If you have mild heart failure and your condition hasn't improved on any other medicine talk to your doctor to see if Remicade is right for you. You may have to take lower doses and have heart testing before  and during treatment.

description_processed.orig: Remicade may not be the best choice if you have advanced heart failure with symptoms. risks_warnings.title: Serious infections
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can increase your risk of serious or life-threatening bacterial, fungal and viral infections. In some cases infections can be reactivated from an inactive virus in your body like tuberculosis (TB) or hepatitis B virus (HBV). You may need to take medicine for TB before you can begin taking Remicade. If you develop symptoms of cough, fever, chills, muscle aches, feel very tired, or you notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, appetite/weight loss, vomiting, change in stool color, stomach discomfort, and skin rash,  tell your doctor and get medical care right away.

risks_warnings.title: Malignancy
risks_warnings.description: Based on how Remicade works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Remicade.

description_processed.orig: Based on how Remicade works, it may lower the body's defenses against malignancies and control how they develop and grow. There appears to be a higher risk of lymphoma, some other cancers, and non-melanoma skin cancer (NMSC) in people who take Remicade.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Remicade can cause nervous system conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and Guillain Barre syndrome. If you currently have a nervous system condition, your doctor will watch you closely while you're taking Remicade since it can make them worse. Let your doctor know right away if you notice numbness or tingling, weakness in arms or legs, vision problems or dizziness.

risks_warnings.title: Blood problems
risks_warnings.description: Remicade can affect blood cells that help you fight infection and stop bleeding. Let your doctor know if you develop a fever that doesn't go away, or you easily bruise, or bleed. You may need to stop taking this medicine.

risks_warnings.title: Liver injury

If liver enzymes are significantly elevated and you have appetite/weight loss, stomach discomfort, vomiting, and notice dark urine, yellowing of skin/eyes, change in stool color, and skin rash you should stop treatment with Remicade until you can be completely assessed,

carousel_items: Rituximab is given as an IV infusion by trained medical staff in a clinic or hospital.
You'll need to be monitored in the clinic in case you have a serious or life-threatening reaction during the infusion, but you can take other medications that'll lower your risk of this happening.
It's very important that you read the Medication Guide before you start taking Rituximab.
Rituximab lowers your immune system's ability to fight infections, so it's important to let your doctor know if you notice a fever, a cough that doesn't go away, or flu-like symptoms.
Use effective birth control while you're taking Rituximab and for 12 months after you finish treatment.
Don't get live vaccines while you're taking Rituximab.

basics.benefits_moa: Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody. It targets a specific protein on white blood cells that makes it easier for your immune system to find and destroy cancerous cells. It also relieves symptoms and slows the progression of Rheumatoid Arthritis.
basics.bottom_line: Rituximab is effective for treating multiple types of cancer and arthritis. That said, you'll need to watch for possibly serious side effects, especially infusion reactions.
downsides: Only your doctor or other trained medical staff can administer Rituximab, so you'll need to go into an office or clinic for every dose.
Not the best choice if you have heart problems.
Rituximab can stay in your body for up to 6 months after you complete treatment. Men and women who are able to have children need to use birth control for up to one year after finishing Rituximab.
Discuss with your doctor the serious heart, kidney, liver, or stomach problems that can happen while on Rituximab.

downsides_processed.orig: Only your doctor or other trained medical staff can administer Rituximab, so you'll need to go into an office or clinic for every dose.
Not the best choice if you have heart problems.
Rituximab can stay in your body for up to 6 months after you complete treatment. Men and women who are able to have children need to use birth control for up to one year after finishing Rituximab.
Discuss with your doctor the serious heart, kidney, liver, or stomach problems that can happen while on Rituximab.

upsides: Treats leukemia, lymphoma, and blood vessel inflammation.
Also treats moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis that hasn't responded to anti-TNF treatment (but you'll need to take methotrexate too).

The chance of having a reaction to the infusion is highest during your first dose, but the risk decreases each time you get Rituximab. It usually happens within 30 minutes to 2 hours after starting the infusion.
Rituximab is a targeted therapy that works differently than chemotherapy. Both work well when they're taken together, especially when treating CLL and NHL.

Your doctor can prescribe medication before your dose so the risk of having this happen is less.

risks_warnings.title: Nervous system effects
risks_warnings.description: Although rare, Rituximab can cause Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML), a serious often fatal brain infection caused by a virus. Unfortunately, it can't be prevented or treated, and if you get it, there's no cure. Let your doctor know right away if you become confused, dizzy, have vision problems, loss of balance or weakness on one side of your body

risks_warnings.title: Skin and mouth reactions
risks_warnings.description: Severe and possibly fatal reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, pemphigus)  can happen anytime and as early as the first day while taking Rituximab. Tell your doctor or get medical help right away if you notice sores or fluid-filled blisters on your skin, lips or inside your mouth or peeling skin that's painful. You may not be able to re-start Rituximab after this reaction.

risks_warnings.title: Kidney injury
risks_warnings.description: Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) happens when cancer cells are broken down very quickly and damage the kidneys. The damage can be so bad that people need dialysis. If you're taking Rituximab for a cancer condition your doctor can give you medicines and take measures to prevent this reaction.

carousel_items: If you're sexually active, you and your partner should use birth control, since Azathioprine can cause birth defects.
If you take Azathioprine for rheumatoid arthritis, your joint damage canâ€™t be reversed, so keep up with your physical therapy and get plenty of rest.
While taking Azathioprine, your body is susceptible to infection; so be sure to wash your hands often and keep distance from with people who are sick.
It is typical to have some nausea when you first start taking Azathioprine; if it's unbearable, let your doctor know.
Don't sun tan while taking this medication. Always use sunscreen and wear a long-sleeved shirt, pants, hat, and sunglasses.

basics.benefits_moa: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant medication. It blocks the production of the white blood cells that kill unfamiliar cells.
basics.bottom_line: Azathioprine is an effective medication for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and transplant rejection, but comes with a heavy list of side effects.
downsides: If you take Azathioprine for rheumatoid arthritis, you'll likely need to take additional medications to control your symptoms.
While taking Azathioprine, you will have to get your blood tested once a week for the first month, every other week for the second and third month, and once every month after that.
Along with other side effects, your hair may begin to change color or fall out when you first start taking Azathioprine, but this is usually temporary.
You'll likely have to take additional medications, like methotrexate to keep your rheumatoid arthritis in remission.

You can still get vaccinated for the flu while taking Azathioprine.
Drinking alcohol is okay while taking Azathioprine.
Most side effects are temporary.

risks_warnings.description: Long-term use of Azathioprine has been reported to cause skin cancer, as well as lymphoma (a cancer of the lymph nodes, which protect our bodies from infection and toxins).

risks_warnings.title: Decreased blood cells
risks_warnings.description: Though your doctor will order tests to make sure the level of Azathioprine in your blood is safe, can cause a decrease in the amount of blood cells your body has. This may also lead to a suppression and toxicity of your bone marrow. People with low to no thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TMPT) activity have a higher chance of this.

risks_warnings.description: If you take Azathioprine for a long time it can increase your risk of infections, make it hard to tell if you have one, take longer to fight, and be more serious.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Azathioprine has been known to cause a decrease in the amount, and quality of sperm temporarily. It has also been known to cause harm to the fetus. For these reasons, it is important to use medically acceptable forms of contraception while receiving Azathioprine. In certain conditions however, the benefits of taking Azathioprine outweigh the risks, and pregnant women should continue taking it.

carousel_items: Don't use alcohol, NSAIDs (anti-inflammatory medications), or stay in the sun too long.
Use birth control and avoid pregnancy for at least 2 months (for women) and 3 months (for men) after you finish Methotrexate.
Drink plenty of liquids to stay hydrated while taking this.
Take the medication exactly as your doctor or pharmacist tells you. Call your doctor or pharmacist if you're confused.

basics.benefits_moa: Methotrexate is an anti-cancer and immunosuppressive medication that treats forms of cancer, arthritis, and psoriasis. For cancer, it helps your body destroy cancer cells by blocking building blocks that cancer cells need to grow. For rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis, it lowers the body's normal immune response and prevents the body from attacking itself.
basics.bottom_line: Methotrexate is a first line treatment for many autoimmune diseases and types of cancer. If you're taking it for a long time, you'll have to get routine blood tests.
downsides: You have to be on birth control for at least 2 to 3 months after you finish Methotrexate since it can cause birth defects.
You have to avoid alcohol and being in the sun too long.
You'll have to get blood tests done if you're taking this long-term because it can cause harmful side effects.

upsides: Recommended as first line treatment for rheumatoid arthritis.
Available as a generic medication. Comes as a tablet, an injection that you give yourself weekly, and as an infusion that you get in your doctor's office or at an infusion center.
If you accidentally take too much, there's an antidote to help your body recover.

risks_warnings.title: Toxicity
risks_warnings.description: You are at higher risk of having toxic symptoms because of too much Methotrexate in your blood if you have kidney disease, or if you have fluid in the abdomen (ascites) or in the lungs (pleural effusion). Your doctor will monitor your body's reaction to Methotrexate very closely if they decide you need to be on Methotrexate.

risks_warnings.title: Liver disease
risks_warnings.description: If you're on Methotrexate for psoriasis, your doctor will have you to do lab tests to check your liver on a regular basis. Acute sudden changes to the liver have been reported, but this has been rare. Call your doctor if you suddenly have pain in your abdomen, you don't feel like eating, or if your skin or the whites of your eyes become yellow.

risks_warnings.title: Lung disease
risks_warnings.description: There have been reports of people on Methotrexate who develop lung disease. This is very rare. Call your doctor immediately if you suddenly get a dry non-productive cough and you don't have a cold or flu.

description_processed.orig: There have been reports of people on Methotrexate who develop lung disease. This is very rare. Call your doctor immediately if you suddenly get a dry non-productive cough and you don't have a cold or flu.

risks_warnings.title: Diarrhea | Sores in the mouth
risks_warnings.description: Call your doctor immediately if you suddenly get diarrhea or if you get sores in your mouth. This could be a sign of too much Methotrexate in your blood, and your doctor may stop the medication or prescribe an antidote.

description_processed.orig: Call your doctor immediately if you suddenly get diarrhea or if you get sores in your mouth. This could be a sign of too much Methotrexate in your blood, and your doctor may stop the medication or prescribe an antidote.

risks_warnings.title: Skin reactions
risks_warnings.description: People have reported severe skin reactions while on Methotrexate which can require hospitalization, or possibly cause death. Call your doctor immediately if you get a high fever and a sudden blistering skin rash.

description_processed.orig: People have reported severe skin reactions while on Methotrexate which can require hospitalization, or possibly cause death. Call your doctor immediately if you get a high fever and a sudden blistering skin rash.

risks_warnings.title: Kidney injury
risks_warnings.description: Tumor lysis syndrome happens when cancer cells are broken down very quickly and damage the kidneys. The damage can be so bad that people need dialysis. If you're taking Methotrexate to treat cancer, your doctor can give you medicines and take measures to prevent this reaction.

carousel_items: Keep the Orencia self-injection refrigerated, but let it rest at room temperature for 30 to 60 minutes before using it.
Each time you use Orencia, be sure to rotate the sites you chose to inject it in. Don't inject it where your skin is tender, bruised, red, or scaly.
If you decide to go with the IV version of Orencia, you will only need to get infusions once a month. The self-injections however need to be taken once a week.
If you get the IV infusion, stay hydrated, try to relax, and ask your nurse to apply dry heat (instant warm packs) to your arm to help find your good veins.

basics.benefits_moa: Orencia is called a DMARD, a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug. It prevents your body from activating cells that cause inflammation.
basics.bottom_line: Orencia slows the progress of rheumatoid arthritis, but can also have serious side effects.
downsides: You'll have to get your blood tested regularly while taking Orencia.
You'll probably have to take other medications to help treat your RA symptoms.
Orencia is pretty expensive.
The IV infusion form of Orencia can cause a reaction, which ranges from a slight itching or warm feeling to more serious complications like low blood pressure and chest pain.
Because RA is chronic disease, you'll likely take Orencia for many years.

upsides: Helps minimize joint damage, lowers symptoms, and prevents future problems.
In a 2-year study that used IV Orencia with methotrexate, more than half of the people had remission and the majority felt significantly better.
People taking [name-common] had no new joint damage after two years.
Taking Orencia allows RA patients to use less prednisone, a steroid that has many side effects.
Orencia can be used without other medications for RA.

Each time you use Orencia, be sure to rotate the sites you chose to inject it in. Don't inject it where your skin is tender, bruised, red, or scaly.
If you decide to go with the IV version of Orencia, you will only need to get infusions once a month. The self-injections however need to be taken once a week.

risks_warnings.title: Use with TNF antagonists
risks_warnings.description: You shouldn't take Orencia with TNF antagonists (other DMARDs like Remicade, Humira, and Enbrel). People taking any of these combinations can experience more infections.

description_processed.orig: You shouldn't take Orencia with TNF antagonists (other DMARDs like Remicade, Humira, and Enbrel). People taking any of these combinations can experience more infections.

risks_warnings.title: Severe allergic reactions
risks_warnings.description: Orencia can cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (swelling of the tongue). This is a medical emergency and you should get medical attention immediately.

description_processed.orig: Orencia can cause hypersensitivity reactions (severe rash, trouble breathing) and angioedema (swelling of the tongue). This is a medical emergency and you should get medical attention immediately.

risks_warnings.title: Live vaccines
risks_warnings.description: You should not be immunized with live vaccines within 3 months of taking Orencia. Children who have RA should catch up on all of their immunizations before starting Orencia.

description_processed.orig: You should not be immunized with live vaccines within 3 months of taking Orencia. Children who have RA should catch up on all of their immunizations before starting Orencia.

risks_warnings.title: Immunosuppression
risks_warnings.description: Orencia can interfere with your immune response and function, meaning that your body can be susceptible to more viruses and infections.
